awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A cognitive dashboard to support clinical decision making in neurosurgery
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to support the ability of neurosurgeons to remove brain tumors or brain tissue that is causing seizures while protecting the patient’s mental function. As many as 4 in 5 neurosurgery patients self-report a cognitive difficulty after surgery that negatively impacts their quality of life. Neurosurgical interventions to remove brain tumors or treat medically refractory epilepsy try not to cause post-operative cognitive deficits in patients, but sometimes the pathological tissue that needs to be removed is involved with brain tissue that supports critical abilities, like the abilities to talk, remember, or move. Because there is inter-individual variability in the precise location of higher critical functions (e.g., language, memory, locomotion), each patient’s brain must be mapped in a personalized way. Ultimately, patients want confidence they will be the same person coming out of brain surgery as they were going into surgery, and clinical teams want tools that support quantitative pre-operative surgical planning and evidence-based projections of post-operative function.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to support the development of a software product that enables neurosurgical teams to track patients’ mental function over the trajectory of their care, i.e., a type of cognitive dashboard. Current practice lacks a tool that identifies brain tissue that, if removed, would result in long-term cognitive deficits. This project’s core deliverable is a turn-key software platform that supports brain mapping protocols, as well as assessment, scoring, archiving and sharing of measures of mental function across the timeline of care of each patient. The software platform will integrate with critical existing systems already in place in all medical centers (e.g., cranial navigation, electroencephlogram (EEG), and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) stimulus display systems). Follow-on work to this project’s core deliverable is based on the premise that data from prior studied patients can be used to train artificial intelligence/machinge learning (AI/ML) algorithms which can then be used to simulate the expected effect of a given surgical plan on a new patient’s future cognitive function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
MindTrace Technologies, Inc. (MindTrace) is developing a novel, patent-pending (PCT/US19/64015) suite of products that integrate multiple sources of information to enable clinicians to plan neurosurgery more effectively in support of the best post-operative quality-of-life (QOL) for their patients. Brain tumors result in a disproportionate rate of cancer mortality and morbidity. Standard of care for treatment of tumors includes maximal safe surgical resection, with extent of surgical resection (EOR) representing a key prognostic indicator of morbidity and mortality. EOR is dependent on the surgeon's ability to distinguish healthy brain tissue from tumor-invaded tissue. When a tumor is adjacent to brain regions that support critical functions, the surgeon seeks to maximize the onco-functional balance: remove as much tumor as possible, while not causing new permanent sensory, motor or cognitive impairments. The ground truth standard-of-care procedure to optimize that balance is an awake craniotomy, with direct electrical stimulation mapping (DES) and/or continuous neuropsychological monitoring throughout the resection. Knowing the location of specific functions with respect to real-time surgical targets allows the clinical team to protect those functions.

This NSF Phase I's scope of work was the development of a software solution for neurosurgeons that supports assessment and scoring of sensory, cognitive, and motor abilities across a brain tumor patient's timeline of care, including in-person and via synchronous tele-health testing, and which integrates with critical existing systems already in place in all medical centers (cranial navigation, EEG, MRI stimulus display systems). The project's focus was to complete development of MindTrace MeasureTM and MindTrace ORTM, which supports administration and scoring of tests of mental function and functional brain mapping in brain tumor patients who are candidates for an awake craniotomy.

There is an important societal need that is directly addressed by this technology: neurosurgical interventions to remove brain tumors or treat medically refractory epilepsy strive to not cause post-operative cognitive deficits in patients. However, as many as 75% neurosurgery patients self-report a post-operative deficit that negatively affects their quality of life. Post-operative cognitive deficits affecting language, vision, hearing, touch or movement lower patients' quality of life and increase morbidity (i.e., disabling impairments). By creating tools that improve patient outcome, patients are able to return to their lives more completely after surgery, which has broad implications for not just their own quality of life, but that of their families, with direct consequences for the broader economy and society.

MindTrace also generates new information that can be used by clinicians to inform patients about a surgical plan's potential implications on their own neurocognitive function and treatment. Most patients are naive as to what parts of the brain support what types of mental functions (compare that to common knowledge about what the stomach, or heart, or lungs do). Educating patients and their families about the broader context of their surgery is important as it advances the broader mission of raising scientific literacy: and importantly increased scientific literacy allows patients and their caregivers to be collaborators in their own care and recovery.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2024
Modified by: Maxwell H Sims
